title: What year did Winston Churchill say “never never never give up”? - Quora

response.answer_text: Written by: John David Olsen, Global Digital Project Manager | Digital Strategist Churchill is misquoted as saying “Never, never, never give up”. Winston Churchill actually said ‘…never give in, never, never, never, never—in nothing, great or small, large or petty—never give in except to convictions of honour and good sense.’ Churchill said this on the 29th of October 1941 in a speech at the school he attended as a boy, Harrow School just outside of Central London. Churchill went on to say: ‘Never yield to force; never yield to the apparently overwhelming might of the enemy.’ Churchill loved to visit his old school and did so many times. On this occasion, his speech, which is so often misquoted, was about twenty minutes long. One can imagine the context of the time of the speech in October of 1941, which were desperate times—before the Americans entered the war in December of that year. Great Britain was very much on her own as Poland, France, Czechoslovakia and the low countries had all fallen in the wake of Hitler’s blitzkrieg (or ‘lightning war’). Incidentally, Churchill had a photographic memory and even late in life he loved to sing the old Harrow School songs which he knew word-for-word.
4th June 1940 {Time jumped to the relevant part towards the end. Although this is the full speech as delivered}:

In a speech delivery to the House of Commons in 4th June of 1940, while he had to answer about the Dunkirk fiasco and respond to the real chances of a German invasion, without casting doubt on an eventual victory.

June 5, 1940, during an address to Parliament. The speech followed the defeat and evacuation of Dunkirk. Churchill admonished the members of parliament to not think of the fall of Dunkirk as a victory, but the retreat that it was. At the same time, he very eloquently bolstered the spirits of the British and the rest of the free world
